etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in John Lindley (1799–1865), botanist and horticulturist. From classical Latin pērōnātus wearing heavy raw-hide boots from pērōn-, pērō thick boot of raw hide (of uncertain origin; perhaps related to ancient Greek πήρα bag, pouch) + -ātus

definitions: Of the stipe of a fungus: having a volva or veil forming a cottony or woolly sheath round its lower part.
